Welcome to the course!

<button type="button" class="collapsible">
Week 36: Introduction
</button>
<div class="content">

##### Tuesday Lecture:

- Introduction to the course
- Introduction to a cognitive construct: working memory

##### Thursday Lab:

- Run in-class online memory-span experiment
- Discuss infrastructure involved in an online experiment

##### Homework:

- Read chapters from Navarro & Foxcroft (2018)
	- Chapter 1
	- Chapter 2
- Read chapters from Hinklelman & Kempthorne (2008)
	- Chapter 1 (Ok to skim some)
	- Chapter 2 (Ok to skim some, especially the math. I have highlighted key points)
	- Chapter 2 section 2.7 (Essential reading!)
- Read Gluck et al Chapter 9 (9.1 required, rest optional)
- Install software  
		- <a href="https://osdoc.cogsci.nl/3.3/download/" target="_blank"> OpenSesame </a>  
		- <a href="https://jasp-stats.org/download/" target="_blank"> JASP </a>  
- Watch and do the <a href="https://osdoc.cogsci.nl/3.3/tutorials/beginner/" target="_blank"> OpenSesame beginner tutorial </a>
</div>

<button type="button" class="collapsible">
Week 37: Experimental Design 1 
</button>
<div class="content">

##### Tuesday Lecture:
- Discuss experimental design at the conceptual level (chapters from Hinklelman & Kempthorne, 2008; Navarro & Foxcroft, 2018)
- Discussion on operationalization
	- DV's
	- IV's
	- Randomization
	- Controls
	- Samples and populations
- Discuss operationalization of working memory in the memory span task

##### Thursday Lab:
- Anatomy of an OpenSesame experiment
  - Discuss tutorial: questions and answers
  - Dissect structure of the Memory Span experiment
		
##### Homework:
- Read Sternberg (1966)
- Identify the sentences in which Sternberg justifies and operationalizes his experiment


</div>
<p></p><p></p>


[//]: # (*******************************************************************************************************************)


<button type="button" class="collapsible">
Week 38: Experimental Design 2
</button>
<div class="content">

##### Tuesday Lecture:
- Recap operationalization from last week
- Discuss how Sternberg justifies and operationalizes his experiment
	
##### Thursday Lab:
- Brainstorm how to construct a task that would measure whether we access working memory in serial or parallel
- Discuss how this could be implemented in OpenSesame

		
##### Homework:
- **Porfolio Assignment 1** (due next week):
		- Summarize a published experiment (Loosli et al (2012):    
			- Justification  
			- Operationalization  
				- Participants (demographic data)  
				- DV’s  
				- IV’s  
			- Data type (Continous, Interval, etc.)  
			- Experimental design  
			- Analysis methods  
			- Conclusions  
			- Possible confounds  
- Read:
	- (Optional: Navarro et al (2019) chapter 6)
	- (Optional: Navarro et al (2019) chapter 7)
	- Required: Navarro et al (2019) chapter 8

</div>

Week 39 Statistical Analysis 1

##### Tuesday Lecture:
- lecture on: 
	- statistical models (modelling relationships)
	- variation
	- distributions
	- test statistics
	- prediction
	- null and alternative hypotheses
	- p-values
	- means
	- standard deviations
	- degrees of freedom
	- logic of NHST

##### Thursday Lab:
- Build a Sternberg experiment in OpenSesame together
- Everyone runs their Sternberg experiment locally on their computer and uploads their data

##### Homework:
- Read Navarro et al (2019) chapter 10
	- bare minimum: read the summary (10.10)
	- a bit more: read 10.3 and 10.5
	- optional: all of chapter 10
